bibl.title: Letter from Foster Kennedy to Philip Showalter Hench, April 9, 1946

div1.p: Kennedy would like to see Hench and will show him the original contract between Walter Reed and Nicanor Fernandez. He believes that America has not given Finlay proper credit.

div1.head: Letter from Foster Kennedy to Philip Showalter Hench, April 9, 1946
div1.opener:
TEL. PLAZA 3-7161
FOSTER KENNEDY, M.D.
410 EAST 57TH STREET
NEW YORK 22, N.Y.
April 9, 1946
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I shall be delighted if you
will come and see me when you are in New York and I
shall show you the original contract between Walter
Reed and Nicanor Fernandez, a Spaniard visiting Cuba
who submitted to inoculation and, I believe, later
died of the experiment. (Whom you mention in your Paper)

Have you read Carlos Finlay's
lecture in 1881 in Philadelphia on the transmission
of yellow fever by mosquito? Many years ago I read it
but have not the reference in my mind. I have always
felt, as has Finlay's family, that Carlos Finlay has
never received, in America, the credit due to him
for his magnificent idea which was the stimulus to
the Walter Reed Commission.

I have just read your splendid
article which you so kindly sent me, “Conquerors of
Yellow Fever,” reprinted from Hygeia,-the best account
I have ever seen of those dramatic and fateful events.
- 2 -
Dr. Philip S. Hench
April 9, 1946
In it you have very handsomely spoken of Finlay.
Perhaps if you could find his Philadelphian address
it would lend precision and substance to what you
say regarding his twenty-year long obsession.

I shall look forward to see-
ing you.
